title: administrator
description: You enjoy working with numbers and data to identify patterns and solve problems. You have a keen eye for detail and are able to see the big picture while also paying attention to the small details.
detailedDescription: You’re a person who likes connecting the dots. You think in systems and see patterns where others might not. You probably enjoy working with computers and a complex spreadsheet doesn’t phase you. You may already have a background in analytics or information systems and are interested in transferring those skills to health care—or you may be in an administrative role looking to upskill.

tabs.title: Motivation
tabs.content: The Analyst likes to develop and maintain systems and solve problems. They often enjoy solving puzzles presented by data.

tabs.title: Skills
tabs.content: This role is skilled at organization, project management, data analysis, and creative problem solving.

tabs.title: Works With
tabs.content: Careers in The Analyst’s path tend to work with medical professionals and computer systems.

tabs.title: Setting
tabs.content: An office or hospital are common workplaces for The Analyst, but they may also work for a technical services or administrative support organization.

tabs.title: Education
tabs.content: Jobs in this field often require college courses in things like biology, computer science, math, and management. Some roles require a bachelor’s or master’s degree.

tabs.title: Experience
tabs.content: People with experience working with computers, databases, or information systems tend to be a good fit for The Analyst’s career path.

stats.title: Growth
stats.description: In employment of health information technologists and medical registrars over the next decade

stats.title: Median Salary
stats.description: For health information technologists and medical registrars, ranging from $30K to $98K averages

stats.title: Job Openings
stats.description: Predicted annually over the next decade due to workers retiring or transferring careers

degreeTabs.title: Master's
degreeTabs.content:
If you do have a bachelor’s degree and want to further specialize your studies, these are some popular master’s in the health information field:

  • Master’s in Health Informatics: This degree can prepare you to analyze data and improve data systems with the goal of improving public health systems, healthcare delivery systems, and patient outcomes.
  • Master’s in Bioinformatics: This degree provides skills in both biotechnology and computer science which opens doors in a wide range of analysis-driven careers.
  • Master’s in Health Care Analytics: This degree focuses more on the data side, helping you comply with key legal, regulatory, and ethical constraints around sensitive client data and practices advanced analysis and reporting techniques.

Colleges and universities have different names for their programs, so your preferred institution might call the degree by a different name—just look for a description that includes both health care and informatics or analytics.

degreeTabs.title: Bachelor's
degreeTabs.content:
If you don’t already have a bachelor’s degree, many universities offer a Bachelor’s in Health Information Management. You can often earn these degrees online.

Colleges and universities have different names for their programs, so your preferred institution might call the degree by a different name—just look for a description that includes both health care and informatics or analytics.
